perturbation.explanation: The original text states that invoices must be paid within 30 days. However, Brazil's Law No. 9.430, Article 85 establishes a 20% penalty for invoices unpaid beyond 30 days. Modifying the payment term to 60 days introduces a contradiction, as Brazilian law does not mandate this extended period and it can cause legal issues related to late payment penalties and interests.

perturbation.explanation: In Brazil, it's unlawful to let interest rates fall to the discretion of the lender. Rates must adhere to legal benchmarks, defined in the original document and in the Brazilian Civil Code. Switching to annual calculations also disrupts the legally consistent monthly scheme and generally should not let the lowest rate be used.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Brazil - Brazilian Civil Code, regarding interest rate regulations

perturbation.original_text: 20.6 This Clause 20 shall survive termination or expiry of this Agreement for a period of five (5) years following such End Date.
perturbation.changed_text: 20.6 This Clause 20 shall survive termination or expiry of this Agreement for a period of one (1) year following such End Date.
perturbation.explanation: According to the Brazilian Intellectual Property Law (Law No. 9.279/96), trade secrets and confidential information can be protected indefinitely as long as they remain secret and have economic value. A confidentiality clause that expires after one year may be insufficient to protect trade secrets under Brazilian law, particularly if the information remains valuable beyond that period.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Brazil - Brazilian Intellectual Property Law (Law No. 9.279/96)
